name: Skull Fractures
info:
A skull fracture is a bone break in your skull.
Your skull is the bone structure that surrounds your brain.
 This head injury is common after vehicle accidents, falls and sports injuries. Some skull fractures are mild and heal on their own. Others may need surgery to repair your skull and prevent complications from affecting your brain. Sourced from Cleveland Clinic

name: Arm Fractures
info: A Arm fracture is a bone break in either of the three bones of your arm (Humerus: the upper arm bone, Ulna: the bone in your forearm on medial side, same side of your pinkie finger, Radius: the bone in your forearm from lateral side, same side of your thumb). May commonly occur from traumas like falls or car accidents. May require to wear a cast for several weeks for healing. Sourced from Cleveland Clinic

name: Phalanges Fractures
info: A Phalanges Fracture is a bone break of one of your phalanges that makes up your finger (each finger makes up three phalanges, while thumb makes up two). Often occur in accidents or due to weakened bones. May require to use a splint (a device similar to a cast to support broken fractures) and may take several weeks for healing. Sourced from Cleveland Clinic

name: Rib Fractures
info: A rib fracture is a bone break in the rib cage. Depending on the severity, ribs that are cracked while painful won't cause much harm to the body compared to ribs broken into fragments and may affect the organs or blood vessals if there's contact. They commonly can occur from falls, car accidents, etc. Healing time may take about six weeks on its own. Sourced from Cleveland Clinic
